p.s: Lady Macbeth tries to convince him by adressingaddressing his feelings/his mind.
She does this first in line 9: Was the hope drunk (...) Hath it slept since?.
With that, she means if Macbeth was drunk as he had the plan/hope of becoming king and where his thoughts about this have gone.
Also, she uses strong choice of words like green and pale (l. 11).
She does this to describe his behavior in a very degrading way to make him feel weak.

Also, by saying that he has to do it if he loves her (l. 13): Such I account thy love, she is again adressingaddressing his feeelings in a very manipulative way, because if he does not follow her commands she could refuse to love him.
Then, she convinces him by telling him that he has to do the necessary things to become king twice.
First, in line 13-15: Art thou afread (...) art in desire?.
She means with that, that if he wishes to become king, he should just do it.
If he wishes that hard to become the king, he should not be that weak if it comes to the necessary actions.
She does this a second time in line 17-18: Letting I dare not (...) the adage?.
Here, she creates the image of a cat wanting to eat fish but not wanting to get wet in order to catch them.
She compares him to the cat, because both know what they and what they have to do, but they do not do it.
Again, this is a very manipulative way of argumenting, because she is comparing him to a weak animal like a cat.
After he encounters, she continues that as he opened his plan to her, he was strong enough to do it and now he is not anymore (l. 24-25): That made you (...), then you were a man.
By saying then you were a man, she shows him as non-masculine or not a real man, because he is not strong enough to continue.
By that, she is again showing him as weak and adressingaddressing his feelings.

She continues by talking about their baby and how much work she had to put into it but she still loves it and that it is the same with Macbeth (l. 30-34): I have given such (...) How tender 'tis love (...) had I sworn as you.
By doing that, she makes him feel like something she has to take care of all the time and now, it is his turn, to give something back by becoming king.
Here, again, she tries to adressaddress his feelings by making him feel weak.
After Macbeth asking about the event of failure, she responds that they fail if they fail, but by doing the correct things they will not fail anyway.
Here, she uses the image of ana musician that is correcting his instrument to play the perfect tone (l. 38): But screw your courage to the sticking-place.
Again, she compares Macbeth to something, in this case to the musician that has to do the right actions to achieve the goal (killing the King = tone of the instrument).
This has the effect of laying all trust in his hands.
If he does the right, he will become king.
By this she is giving him an important role in their plan.
While she describes the plan of murderung the kingKing, she is using many strong adjectives to specify the actions Macbeth has to perform to give him a more dear vision of what he has to do.
This is to calm him down.

She uses adjectives like soundly(has something mysterious) or swinish (to show that the King will sleep very deep and will not notice them) or unguarded (to, again, show that the King will not be able to defend himself).
She also uses another image in line 34: warder of the brain to show (again) to Macbeth how secure their plan is.
This works by the image she created, because if the guard of the brain from the kingsKing's guards is knocked out, who could stop them?
In conclusion, you can see that Lady Macbeth is trying to convince Macbeth in a very manipulative way.
She does this by adressingaddressing his feelings like his love to her or by describing him as something weak.
By this he is trying to be the strong man she wants/needs and is doing what she wants.
